conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start moving simultaneously from rest, from the same position, and in the same direction. The velocity-time graph of their motion is provided.

The velocity-time graph shows that particle A accelerates to 2v₀ at t = t₀, maintains this velocity until 2t₀, then decelerates to zero at 3t₀ and remains stationary. Particle B accelerates more slowly, reaching v₀ at 3t₀, maintains this velocity until 5t₀, then decelerates to zero at 6t₀.

premise: The velocity-time graph shows the motion of particles A and B.
conclusion: The position x(t) of each particle can be determined by integrating their respective velocity functions.

premise: The velocity-time graph and integration of velocity functions.
conclusion: For particle A: From 0 to t₀, x_A(t) = v₀t²/t₀. From t₀ to 2t₀, x_A(t) = v₀t₀ + 2v₀(t-t₀) = 2v₀t - v₀t₀. From 2t₀ to 3t₀, x_A(t) = x_A(2t₀) + area of triangle = 3v₀t₀ + (3t₀-t)(t-2t₀)v₀/t₀. After 3t₀, x_A(t) = 3v₀t₀ (constant position).

premise: The velocity-time graph and integration of velocity functions.
conclusion: For particle B: From 0 to 3t₀, x_B(t) = v₀t²/(6t₀). From 3t₀ to 5t₀, x_B(t) = x_B(3t₀) + v₀(t-3t₀) = v₀t/2 - v₀t₀/2. From 5t₀ to 6t₀, x_B(t) = x_B(5t₀) + area of triangle = 2v₀t₀ + (6t₀-t)(t-5t₀)v₀/t₀. After 6t₀, x_B(t) = 3v₀t₀ (constant position).

premise: The position functions x_A(t) and x_B(t) derived from integration.
conclusion: At t = 3t₀: x_A(3t₀) = 3v₀t₀ and x_B(3t₀) = v₀(3t₀)²/(6t₀) = 3v₀t₀/2.

premise: The position functions x_A(t) and x_B(t) derived from integration.
The position functions x_A(t) and x_B(t) derived from integration.
conclusion: The distance between particles is d(t) = |x_A(t) - x_B(t)|.
